maps.text: Part of map of Asia highlighting the region from Mesopotamia to the Zagros Mountains in Iran, representing the areas occupied by the ancient Sumerians (Kessler, P. L., , Map of Sumer). The area is marked approximately to provide the reader with a clearer visualization

common.text:
### Introduction

The city of Awan, mentioned in the Sumerian King List, does not have a clearly established location. It is possible that it was situated near Susa, in Iran (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>).

The first reference to the city of Awan dates to around <htdate0>, when King Enmebaragesi invaded the region of Elam, in what is considered the first recorded military conflict in history (<htcite3>; <htcite4>; <htcite5>).

#### The Ancient Dynasties

Although there is no doubt about the existence of the city, the same cannot be said regarding the rulers mentioned in ancient texts.

The Sumerian King List (**Figure 2**), for instance, records three kings who supposedly reigned for 356 years (<htcite6>); however, none of their names have survived the passage of time.
Figure 2: Sumerian King List. © Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford (Ashmolean Image Library).

In addition to the Sumerian King List, there is another list of kings found in Susa, known as “The Twelve Kings of Awan” (<htcite0>). In this list, although the names of the kings have endured, no information is provided about their relationships or the duration of their reigns (<htcite1>).

Despite the lack of genealogical and historical data concerning most of the figures mentioned, some evidence allows us to establish a possible synchronism, placing the supposed kings from the second list around the time of Sargon. This leads to the conclusion that the Elamites with whom Sargon fought were likely from Awan, not Susa (<htcite2>).

All this panorama of disconnected figures leads us to a reflection:
Reflexão 1: Sobre árvores genealógicas

#### Time Estimates

When analyzing the information presented in the two king lists and distributing the possible years (<htcite0>) equally among the rulers, we obtain the following result:
- Considering the reign of one king (36 years) (<htcite1>), this value is subtracted from the total of 356 years, and the remainder is divided between the other two kings: (356 - 36)/2. Thus, each would have ruled for approximately 160 years.
- Assuming that the list of Awan’s kings represents consecutive reigns, it would have begun around <htdate0> and ended approximately in <htdate1>. Based on these values, we can estimate an average duration of 18 years and 6 months per king (2500 - 2278)/12.

It is evident that the Sumerian King List presents improbable and much greater values than those found in the Awan King List, which was written between <htdate2> and <htdate3> (<htcite2>).

Reflection 2: On Time

How can we explain this large discrepancy between the time spans in the Sumerian King List and the Twelve Kings of Awan?

#### A Mathematical Solution

The time periods attributed to certain reigns in the Sumerian King List, which are incompatible with human lifespans, are at the very least questionable (<htcite0>) and lead us to consider them non-literal or symbolic.

We know that in Mesopotamia, tablets have been discovered that depict “triple diagonals,” showing square relationships similar to what we now call the **Pythagorean Theorem** (<htcite1>; <htcite2>). Therefore, it is possible to assume that the numbers presented in these lists may have a mathematical rather than historical meaning (<htcite3>).

In his study, Dr. Young demonstrates that these squares appear within the recorded periods (<htcite4>):
- Intervals showing the presence of squares: 900 (30 × 30), 625 (25 × 25), 324 (18 × 18);
- Some periods, such as those of Awan, result from the sum of squares: (4 × 4) + (10 × 10);
- The number 7 and its multiples appear in various contexts: 319 (5 × 5 × 5 × 5 × 5 + 70), 177 (77 + 10 × 10), 491 (7 × 13 + 20 × 20), 2.310 (7 × 11 × 30).

Despite this evidence, as Dr. Young points out, there is no proof that the Sumerians possessed such an advanced level of mathematical knowledge (<htcite5>).

history.text: The information obtained from the Sumerian King List only allows us to state that there were three kings in Awan, who ruled for a total of 356 years. Nothing more can be concluded from this list (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).
We can only deduce that this is the first mentioned king (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).
We can only deduce that this is the second mentioned king, with no indication of any relation to the previous one (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

This is the third and last king mentioned in the Sumerian King List for the city of Awan, he ruled by 36 years, completing a total period of 356 years (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>).

His name is the only one, among the three kings, that has been partially preserved (<htcite3>).

families.name: Dynasty of Awan (12 kings of Awan) — The 7 Unknown

history.text:
There is no known connection between the supposed kings mentioned in the *Sumerian King List* and the second list found in Susa, Iran (<htcite0>).

Although it is not known precisely when this list was written, the surviving version was probably composed between <htdate0> and <htdate1> (<htcite1>).

The list under study contains many names that cannot be considered historical, as these individuals are not mentioned in any other known source. On the other hand, since the eighth king can be associated with a reference from the time of Sargon, it is understood that the list likely begins around <htdate2> (<htcite2>; <htcite3>).
Apart from being the first figure mentioned in the Susa list, nothing else can be stated about him (<htcite0>).
Apart from being the second figure mentioned in the Susa list, nothing else can be stated about him (<htcite0>).
Apart from being the third figure mentioned in the Susa list, nothing else can be stated about him (<htcite0>).
Apart from being the fourth figure mentioned in the Susa list, nothing else can be stated about him (<htcite0>).
Apart from being the fifth figure mentioned in the Susa list, nothing else can be stated about him (<htcite0>).
Además de ser la sixth figura mencionada en la lista de Susa, no se puede afirmar nada más sobre él (<htcite0>).
Además de ser la seventh figura mencionada en la lista de Susa, no se puede afirmar nada más sobre él (<htcite0>).

families.name: Awan Dynasty (12 Kings of Awan) — Historical Kings

history.text: The kings mentioned in this dynasty were contemporaries of Sargon and began to be documented from <htdate0> onward (<htcite0>).

The eighth king on the list of Awan’s rulers (<htcite0>) is the first whose existence can be confirmed. An inscription dated to <htdate0> explicitly mentions “Luh-ishshan” as a vassal of King Sargon of Akkad (<htcite1>; <htcite2>). Possibly, this title was given after Sargon’s conquest of the region of Elam, as described in **Figure 3** (<htcite3>).
Figure 3: Prism from Library of Ashurbanipal. © Trustees of the British Museum (The British Museum).
It is possible that shortly after Sargon’s invasion, King Luhishshan died and was succeeded by his son (<htcite0>).

Reflection 3: On Reality

Many ancient texts, like the ones we are studying, mention people whose existence has never been verified. For this reason, these figures cannot be considered historical — that is, real and proven individuals.

Have you ever read a text that seemed to describe real people, but when you looked for additional sources from the same period, you discovered they weren’t?
A copy of an inscription in Old Babylonian explicitly mentions a relationship between the eighth and ninth kings, indicating that there was offspring (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).
Mentioned in a copy of an inscription in Old Babylonian (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

His existence is confirmed by a copy of an inscription in Old Babylonian (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

The spelling used in this text differs from that in the ancient copy (“Hishiprashini”); however, this variation is considered plausible (<htcite2>).

During his reign, Rimush, the son of Sargon, once again carried out military campaigns in the region of Elam (<htcite3>; <htcite4>)
Apart from being the tenth figure mentioned in the Susa list, nothing else can be stated about him (<htcite0>).

His relationship with the other kings cannot be confirmed; however, there are indications that he may have existed.

A treaty known as the “Treaty of Naram-Sin”, signed around <htdate0>, mentions an unidentified king or leader who may have been Hita (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

Kutik-Inshushinak is the last king mentioned in the list of the “Twelve Kings of Awan” (<htcite0>). In some sources, he appears identified as **Puzur-Inshushinak** (<htcite1>).

Puzur-Inshushinak is documented in at least twelve inscriptions. Thanks to records from the Third Dynasty of Ur, it can be stated that he lived around <htdate0> (<htcite2>). This chronological gap, compared with the period when King Hita would have been mentioned in an inscription, leads to several scenarios proposed by Potts (<htcite3>):
- Puzur-Inshushinak may not have belonged to the royal lineage of Awan.
- The list of kings may be entirely fictitious.

In addition to the references found in Potts’s work, there is also a dedicatory cone exhibited at the British Museum (**Figure 4**), in which the name of Puzur-Inshushinak is mentioned:
Figure 4: Dedicatory cone. © Trustees of the British Museum (The British Museum).

Some data presented by Potts reinforce the hypothesis that the list of kings might have been a later fabrication. For instance, Puzur-Inshushinak is described with different titles—initially as a *governor*, and later as a *king (lugal)* (<htcite0>).

One of the most notable aspects of his reign was the possible conquest of territories such as Susa (modern Iran), along with a direct confrontation with Ur, which would have established him as a local ruler (<htcite1>; <htcite2>).

Reflection 4: I Am Not There

Texts that are thousands of years old rarely mention people in general. They are narratives focused on kings or leaders, as we have seen in this study.

Have you ever read an ancient text thinking it spoke about humanity, when in fact it only referred to a few individuals?

exercise_v2.question: Is the Awan dynasty mentioned in the Sumerian king list the best documented?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: There is no reliable information about these supposed kings; therefore, it is one of the least documented dynasties.

exercise_v2.question: Does the Awan dynasty mentioned in the list of the 12 kings of Awan include verified individuals?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: According to the documents known so far, at least three kings are recognized as historical figures. Even so, as we saw with the last king, it is likely that the lineage was largely fabricated.
